question: The antenna of an Airborne Weather Radar is stabilised:

choices.choice: in pitch and roll whether the stabilisation is on or off.
in pitch and roll but only when 0° tilt has been selected.

explanation: the ON position the system is energised and the aerial is automatically stabilised in PITCH and ROLL. A lopsided or asymmetric display probably indicates that the stabilisation has failed. Switching to the STAB OFF position will lock the scanner to the pitch and roll axes of the aircraft.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: A frequency used by airborne weather radar is:
explanation:
Frequency

Weather radar operates between 9 GHz and 10 GHz in the SHF band.

A frequency of 9 GHZ gives a wavelength of 3cm.

Pulse radar is used with a PRF of about 400 to 550 pulses a second.

This limits the theoretical maximum range to between 200NM and 300NM.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The mapping mode of Airborne Weather Radar utilises:

choices.choice: a pencil/weather beam from 70 nm to 150 nm.
a cosecant/fan shaped beam which is effective to 150 nm.
a pencil/weather beam with a maximum range of 70 nm.
a cosecant/ fan shaped beam effective 50 nm to 70 nm.

explanation: For the basic monochrome AWR with a maximum range of 150nm, the cosecant (fan-shape) beam is used for mapping up to about 70nm by selecting MAP. To map beyond 70 nm, the pencil beam is used by selecting the MAN position
subject: Radio Navigation

question: Airborne weather radar operates on a frequency of:

choices.choice: 8800 MHz because gives the best returns from all types of precipitation
9375 MHz because it gives the best returns from rainfall associated with Cb
9.375 GHz because this frequency is best for detecting aircraft in flight.

explanation:
Weather radar operates between 9 GHz and 10 GHz in the SHF band. A frequency of 9 GHZ gives a wavelength of 3cm.

A frequency higher than 9375 MHz would produce returns from smaller droplets and cause unnecessary clutter whereas a lower frequency would fail to produce sufficient returns to highlight the area of turbulence.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The centre of a small island is identified at the intersection of the 60° left bearing line and 15nm range arc of an airborne weather radar. If the aircraft’s heading and height are 035° (M) and 42,500ft what QTE and range should be plotted in order to obtain a fix from the island? (variation is 20°W)
explanation:
60° left of 035° =335° Magnetic

“VARIATION WEST “  “MAGNETIC BEST”

with variation 20° west , true bearing is 315°true

 

 

QTE – True FROM station

Be careful! Question asks for “true bearing of the aircraft from the island” so it will be reciprocal of 315°= 135°

Ground Range (nm) = √(S² – H² ) = √225 – 49) = √176= 13 nm

[ S = slant range (nm) and H = height (nm) ]
subject: Radio Navigation

question: An airborne weather radar is required to detect targets up to a maximum range of 200 nm. Ignoring pulse length and flyback in the CRT calculate the maximum PRR.
explanation:
Max Theoretical Range = c / 2 x PRF

Where c = speed of light 3 x 10^8 m/s

If using C as m/s then also convert 200 nm to meters

or use C as 162,000 nautical miles / second

200 = 162000 / 2 PRF

PRF = 405 pps
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The radar in an aircraft at FL370 detects a cloud at 60 nm. The cloud disappears when the tilt is selected to 2° UP. If the beamwidth of the radar is 6°, at what altitude are the tops of the clouds?
explanation:
Height of Cloud above or below the aircraft (ft) = Range in NM x (Tilt – 1/2 Beam Width) x 100

Tilt 2 degree up means that the center of the beam is 2° up.

Since the beam has a width i.e. 6° degrees, the bottom of the beam is below the horizon.

Anyhow, just use the formula and preserve the sign of the angles.

If the answer is a minus figure then the cloud tops are below the aircraft, if plus then they are above.

Height of Cloud above or below the aircraft (ft) = Range in NM x (Tilt – 1/2 Beam Width) x 100

=60 x (2° – 3°) x 100

= -6000 ft

So the cloud tops are at 37,000 – 6000 = 31,000 ft.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: A prominent island is identified on the 30° right bearing line and the 10 nm range marker of an airborne weather radar. If the heading is 045° (T) and the aircraft is at FL360 what range and bearing should be plotted in order to obtain a fix?
explanation:
Aircraft True Heading = 045°

True heading 045° relative bearing 30°= True bearing to island 075°

Be careful! Question asks for “true bearing of the aircraft from the island” so it will be reciprocal of 075° I.e 255°

Ground Range (nm) = √(S² – H² ) = √100-36) = √64= 8 nm

[ S = slant range (nm) and H = height (nm) ]
subject: Radio Navigation

subject: Radio Navigation

question: An Airborne Weather Radar system uses a frequency of 9 GHz because:

choices.choice: it has a short wavelength so producing higher frequency returns.
the short wavelength allows signals to be reflected from cloud water droplets of all sizes.
the wavelength is such that reflections are obtained only from the larger water droplets.
the frequency penetrates clouds quite easily enabling good mapping of ground features in the mapping mode.

explanation:
Weather radar operates between 9 GHz and 10 GHz in the SHF band.

A frequency of 9 GHZ gives a wavelength of 3cm

 

 

For a given transmission power a 3 cm wavelength will give the best returns from large water droplets. Wavelengths of 10 cm and above produce few weather returns.
subject: Radio Navigation
